Review
Nanomaterials and plants: Positive effects, toxicity and the remediation of metal and metalloid pollution in soil
Yi Zhu a, Fang Xu a, Qin Liu a, Ming Chen b,c,⁎, Xianli Liu a,⁎⁎, Yanyan Wang d, Yan Sun b,c, Lili Zhang a a School of Environmental Science & Engineering, Hubei Polytechnic University, Huangshi 435003, PR China b College of Environmental Science and Engineering, Hunan University, Changsha 410082, PR China c Key Laboratory of Environmental Biology and Pollution Control (Hunan University), Ministry of Education, Changsha 410082, PR China d School of Land Resources and Environment, Jiangxi Agricultural University, Nanchang 330045, PR China
H I G H L I G H T S G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T
• The combination of phytoremediation and nanomaterials can increase the remediation efficiency of heavymetal pollution. • Some nanomaterials can promote plant growth and improve the uptake of metals by plants. • The toxicity of heavy metals in soil can be reduced by a part of nanomaterials under the moderate concentrations.

Currently, the pollution of metals and metalloids in the soil has attracted considerable attention. Phytoremediation is considered an environmentally friendly means of remediating pollution, but often takes a long time to perform. Therefore, the combination of plants and nanomaterials in environmental management has attracted the attention of many researchers because some nanomaterials can promote the germination of plant seeds and the growth of whole plants. However, when the concentration of nanomaterials is not controlled properly, certain toxicity will be produced. This paper reviews research on the combination of plant and nanomaterials for the remediation of contaminated environments, as well as on the effects of nanomaterials on plants.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In recent years, due to the continuous development of various industrial technologies (Xu et al., 2016b; Xu et al., 2017), some soil has been contaminated to varying degrees by different types of pollutants. Sources of metals andmetalloids in the soil are diverse (e.g., rocks, agricultural activities, mining and smelting) (Chen et al., 2015). As these pollutants cannot be degraded, the soil ecosystem can be destroyed, limiting the growth of soil microorganisms and plants. These pollutants inhibit the development of plant roots and leaves, pollute drinking water, and cause harm to the human body. Therefore, the issue of soil pollutionmust be urgently addressed. Existing contaminated soil remediation technologies include physical, chemical and biological methods. These methods are often costly and time-consuming. For example, the microbial remediation method is limited in that not all microbes are highly adaptable to the environment, which cannot guarantee the remediation of contaminated soil (Chen et al., 2015). Thus, they are not the best tools for addressing issues of environmental pollution faced today (Chen et al., 2015).
Conversely, phytoremediation is a form of technology that uses green plants to transfer, transform, or absorb pollutants such as metals and metalloids (Jin et al., 2016) such that phytoremediation can limit their harm to the environment. In addition to phytoremediation, another technology, i.e., nanotechnology, is also found to an effective method for pollution remediation. Nanomaterials are materials with at least one dimension across three dimensions ranging from 1 nm to 100 nm (Xu and Lee, 2016). In recent years, several studies have proved that it is feasible to use nanomaterials to remediate different kinds of contaminants in soil such as nano TiO2, nano Fe3O4, nano Ag, NZVI (nano zero valent iron), nano CeO2, nano Zn, nano Co, nano Ni, nano SnO2, NHAP (nano hydroxyapatite), NCB (nano carbon black), and NHAP@BC (biochar supported nano hydroxyapatite), which can be used to remove metals such as Cr, Cu, Pb, Zn and Cd from soil (Zhang et al., 2018; Singh and Lee, 2016; Xing et al., 2016; Mousavi et al., 2018; Huang et al., 2018; Gong et al., 2017). Different nanomaterials have different remediation effects on soil contaminated with heavy metals. In addition, immobilization effects on heavy metals in contaminated soil by different particle sizes of nanomaterials vary, representing another factor influencing the effects of heavy metal restoration (Xing et al., 2016). Naturally, researchers wanted to combine the advantages of these twomethods as a newpotential pollutant restoration technique (Gong et al., 2018).
With the efforts of many researchers, the combination of nanomaterials and plants has become an effective way to remediate polluted environments. For example, cardboard mustard and NZVI work together to remediate Cr contaminated soil, which not only reduces Cr content in plants, but which also promotes plant growth
(Su et al., 2016). When the concentration of heavy metals is high, the rate of heavy metals removal and the biomass can be improved by using Lolium perenne L. combined with NZVI (Huang et al., 2018). Most of such studies have shown that adding proper concentrations of nanomaterials to soil will have the best remediation effects when combinedwith plants. Nano ZnO can also affect the growth and biomass accumulation of Arabidopsis and regulate chlorophyll synthesis (Wang et al., 2015). NHAP can increase soil pH and fix Pb, thus reducing the toxicity of Pb and Cu to Lolium perenne L. (Xing et al., 2016). Therefore, Lolium perenne L. can survive in soil with Pb concentrations of 800 mg/kg (Jin et al., 2016). However, excessively high concentrations of nanomaterials can have a negative impact on plant growth and soil remediation (Chen et al., 2017b). For example, low concentrations of NZVI promote the growth of Lolium perenne L. roots while high concentrations inhibit biomass (Huang et al., 2018). Nano CeO2 affects the biomass of Triticum aestivum L. leaves, causing damage to the leaves (Priester et al., 2017) and affecting increases in grain proteins. In addition, the harvesting period of Triticum aestivum L. spikes has been extended to some extent (Rico et al., 2015). Ibrahim et al. (2016) found that themain obstacles to nanomaterial application include particle aggregation and separation and environmental conditions.
The remediation effectiveness of pollutants is not only related to the concentration of nanomaterials and plant species but also to the length of remediation time. For example, the longer soil treatment with nanomaterials occurs, the better the immobilization effect on Pb (Yang et al., 2016b). In sum, some nanomaterials have positive effects on plant growth, and so they are conducive to the phytoremediation of pollutants in the environment. However, some nanomaterials also have toxic effects on plants as shown in Fig. 1.

sections.heading: 2.1. Positive effects of nanomaterials on plants
sections.text:
The growth conditions of plants are related to the external environment and to nutrients absorbed. Some studies have shown that the addition of nanomaterials to the soil has a significant effect on plants (Table 1). For example, the addition of nano TiO2 can promote soybean growth by changing the chlorophyll or carotene of soybean, which is supposed to increase the photosynthesis rate of soybeans (Singh and Lee, 2018). Similarly, adding 5 g/kg NHAP to soil can increase soil pH, fix Pb, increase the biomass of Lolium perenne L., and promote the growth of Lolium perenne L. (Ding et al., 2017). Some studies have also been conducted on the relationship between nanomaterials and crops in soils. For instance, the effects of nano Fe3O4 on crops were investigated. It was found that nano Fe3O4 had no effect on the germination rate, plant growth and chlorophyll content of Triticum aestivum L.
However, after five days of the hydroponic cultivation of Triticum aestivum L. plants with nano Fe3O4 it was observed that nano Fe3O4 enhanced Triticum aestivum L. antioxidant enzyme activity, which was beneficial for Triticum aestivum L. growth (Iannone et al., 2016). Moreover, studies have shown that in greenhouse conditions, the addition of a certain concentration of nanoCeO2 to soil not only increases the biomass of Triticum aestivum L. but also increases the height of the plant (Du et al., 2015) (Fig. 1). In addition, nanomaterials also have a certain impact on soil remediation. Nanomaterials generally cover a large specific surface area, include microporous channels with network structures, and present relatively high levels of adsorption capacity (Yang et al., 2016b). These characteristics afford them a certain adsorption effect, leaving the growth of plants in soil contaminated with heavy metals unrestricted.
The period of exposure to nanomaterials is an influencing factor of plant growth. Romeh (2018) found that Plantago L. can degrade and remediate polar cleavage product Fipronil within 6 days and that adding NHAP and NCB to contaminated soil grown with Lolium perenne L. can be used for phytoremediation over a short period (Huang et al., 2015).
Therefore, pollution remediation with the combined use of plants and nanomaterials mainly involves two factors. One involves affecting the internal structure of plants with different nanomaterials such as chlorophyll and carotenoid to promote plant growth. Another involves using nanomaterials combined with plants to adsorb heavy metals or
metal-like metals in the soil. Since nanomaterials have positive effects on crops and promote crop growth, it will be a good idea to use them for agricultural development in the future at appropriate concentrations.

sections.heading: 2.2. Toxicity of nanomaterials to plants
sections.text:
Adverse effects of nanomaterials on biology (Chen et al., 2016; Chen et al., 2017a; Chen et al., 2017c; Chen et al., 2017d; Chen et al., 2017e) and especially the toxicity of nanomaterials to plants have been reported in many previous works. It has also been shown that carbon nanomaterials can inhibit the absorption of plant nutrients (Chen et al., 2018). Through recent studies the toxicity of nanomaterials has been determined and has been found to inhibit plant protein content, chlorophyll, carotenoids and biomass (Fig. 1). Nanomaterials can also extend the harvest period of crop Triticum aestivum L. (Table 2). Despite plants being able to excrete potentially toxic elements, nanoparticles are transferred from plant roots to plant leaves and then enter the food chain (Vittori Antisari et al., 2018).
Triticum aestivum L. in northern China is a staple food, but some research suggests that nano CeO2 changes the content of amino acid and affects increases in grain protein levels and the development of Triticum aestivum L. grains (Du et al., 2015). In general, Triticum aestivum L. production is affected in five respects: the growth of Triticum aestivum L.

NZVI has a certain inhibitory effect on the carotenoid and chlorophyll of rice, which also affects the photosynthesis of rice, thus reducing the biomass of plants (Wang et al., 2016). According to such research, the morphology of NZVI in soil is different, and so the corresponding effect on plants is different. It has an inhibitory effect on rice seedlings (Wang et al., 2016). In addition to crop quality, nano CeO2 can also have a certain impact on crop growth. At low concentrations, nano CeO2 can promote plant growth and increase biomass and chlorophyll content levels, and it can also extend the harvesting period of Triticum aestivum L. ears and affect yields of Triticum aestivum L. ears. It has been found that adding 500mg·kg−1 nano ZnO to soil leads to an accumulation of a large amount of Zn in Gycin emax (L.) Merr. plants, thus preventing Gycin emax (L.) Merr. from producing seeds (Rico et al., 2015). Although plants can inhibit the toxicity of certain elements, the metal components of nanomaterials are still transferred from plant
roots to plant parts in contact with air and edible leaves, thus entering the food chain (Vittori Antisari et al., 2018). Synthetic materials have the same drawbacks. Artificially manufactured nano ZnO can be transferred to plant parts aboveground, which has a certain impact on the biomass of plant leaves and which leads to a decrease in the dry weight of plant leaves (Priester et al., 2017). Researchers have evaluated the effect of nanomaterials on crops through themeasurement of leaf transpiration, stomatal conductance and net photosynthesis. Corresponding results show that nanomaterials significantly reduce the fresh weight of plants and their average biomass, and root elongation was significantly reduced when the concentration was 50 mg/L (Vittori Antisari et al., 2018).
Nanomaterials have toxic effects on the environment and nutrition chain (Fernandes et al., 2017). High concentrations of oxidized nanomaterials have certain toxic effects, mainly resulting in plant growth retardation, growth inhibition, etc. The absorption of water and nutrients by the leaves and roots of plants shows that different parts of plants are subject to different toxicity levels (Song and Lee, 2016).

sections.heading: 3. Nanomaterials work together with plants to remediate soil contaminated with metals and metalloids
3.1. Phytoremediation of contaminated soil with metals and metalloids
sections.text:
In recent years, many researchers have conducted studies on phytoremediation (Table 3). Studies have shown that leguminous plants have a symbiotic relationship with AMF and can remediate Pb
contaminated soil (Yang et al., 2015). It was shown that Limnobium laevigatum and Ludwigia peploides are highly adaptable to the external climate and to harsh environments, and Pb concentrations in plant roots decrease with time (Fernández San Juan et al., 2018). In addition, other plants such as vetiver and compositae exhibit similar signs of tolerance (Chand et al., 2016; Nikolić and Stevović, 2015), and their growth is not affected by the toxicity of Cu, Zn and Cd (Siddiqi and Husen, 2016). They can also stabilize Cr, Pb, Ni, Fe, Mg, Cd and Zn (Gautam and Agrawal, 2017). According to the growth characteristics of plants, Cd, Pb and other heavy metals generally accumulate in the roots and stems of vetiver (Siddiqi and Husen, 2016). However, some nanomaterials can transfer Pb between roots, and leaves can be reduced to a certain extent to protect plants exposed to air (Yang et al., 2015). However, metals such as Cr accumulating in Tagetes erecta L. root are often found in higher concentrations than in the ground (Coelho et al., 2017). For soil contaminated with Cd, Cu, and Zn, vetiver has superior remediation effects than tall fescue under other conditions and especially for the remediation of Cd contaminated soil (Siddiqi and Husen, 2016). In turn, Gautam and colleagues utilized vetiver for the improvement of soil containing heavy metals and finally found that Vetiveria zizanioides (L.) Nash can cause Mn and Cu to move from roots to stems (Gautam and Agrawal, 2017). In addition, Banerjee et al. planted vetiver in mineral soil with accumulated heavy metals and found that the use of vetiver could effectively restore soil contaminated with iron ore (Banerjee et al., 2016). Studies have shown that ferns aremore capable of remediating As-contaminated soil than other hyperaccumulating plants, which can reduce concentrations of As in the soil (Fayiga and Saha, 2016). Hyper accumulator Sedum alfredii also not only remediates Cd pollution but also removes nitrates from the soil (Tang et al., 2017). Moreover, in cases of adequate nutrition, it can improve the enrichment capacity of ferns in soil, thus accelerating the absorption and removal of As by ferns (Fayiga and Saha, 2016).
Another important factor shaping the process of plant remediation is the concentration of heavy metals. Research by Chand et al. shows that the higher the concentration of heavymetals applied, the higher the content of heavymetals in plants, and the absorption of plant leaves on Cr, Ni and Cd is greater than that of roots and stems (Chand et al., 2016). Coelho and colleagues showed that the higher the concentration of Cr in nutrient solution, the higher Cr accumulation levels are in plants (Coelho et al., 2017). Choudhury et al. used Indian mustard and Tagetes erecta L for a heavy metals uptake experiment on river sediment. Their results show that the extraction rate of Cr, Pb and Zn is higher in Indian mustard and that the extraction rate of Cr, Cu and Zn is higher in Tagetes erecta L (Choudhury et al., 2016). In addition, plant sensitivity to different heavy metals varies. For example, a comparison of the sensitivity of Pelargonium hortorum Bailey to various heavy metals reveals the following: Cr N Cd NNi N Pd (Chand et al., 2016). The same plant can also vary in its accumulation of different heavy metals. For instance, Cd accumulation in edible parts of rapeseed is greater than that of Pb (Yang et al., 2016a).

sections.heading: 3.2. Nanomaterials combined with plants to remediate soil contaminated with metals and metalloids
3.2.1. NZVI combined with plants
sections.text:
Currently, the extensive application of metals and metalloids also comes with serious hazards that cannot be ignored. Thus, the combination of nanomaterials and plants has been applied in various fields such as for environmental pollution remediation. NZVI combined with three plants (Alpinia calcarata,Ocimum sanctum and Cymbopogon citratus) has been used to remediate endosulfan contaminated soil; the gas chromatography and electron capture method (GC-ECD) has been used to analyze soil samples with endosulfan. At the start of a week, the removal rate of endosulfan can reach N80% (Pillai and Kottekottil, 2016). Studies have shown that when the concentration of NZVI is 10%, it has the best immobilization effect, and the availability of As is relatively low, promoting the growth of Hordeum vulgare L. plants and reducing the
absorption of As (Gil-Diaz et al., 2016; Zhang et al., 2018). Other studies have found higher concentrations of Fe in Hordeum vulgare L. root than in soil treated with NZVI. Fe adsorption by Hordeum vulgare L. plants was found to be unfavorablewith no significant difference in concentrations of elements in the shoots and roots of growing plants (Wang et al., 2016). Cd not only reduces plant biomass but also inhibits plant absorption of iron (Su et al., 2016). Another study confirmed this aswell (Singh and Lee, 2016). NZVI can effectively increase deposits of Cd, thereby reducing the utilization of Cd, and the activity of enzymes increases with the reduction of heavy metals (Huang et al., 2016). Su et al. studied Cd accumulation in plants in the presence of NZVI using the content of Cd in plant roots, stems and leaves as a measurement index (Su et al., 2016). The results show that low concentrations of NZVI inhibits Cd accumulation (Gong et al., 2017), which can reduce Cd content in plants and promote plant growth (Su et al., 2016). Cd inhibits root tip growth, turning leaves brown and yellow, reducing water content in plants, inhibiting photosynthesis and even killing plants (A. El-Amier et al., 2017). It was found that adding NZVI to contaminated soil could reduce Cd content in plants and promote plant growth. Some researchers have also used different plants for the removal of Cd together with nanomaterials in waste water. The concentration of nanomaterials can affect deposition, but improved levels of nanomaterial stability are sufficient, and removal effects of Cd inwastewater are optimalwith a pH of 3 and a temperature of 25 °C (Huang et al., 2015). High concentrations of NZVI inhibit plant growth and leaf biomass (Huang et al., 2018). Gao et al. proved that Impatiens I. balsamina exhibit a high tolerance of and accumulation capacities for Pb by treating I. balsamina using different concentrations of NZVI. Rates of I. balsamina root and leaf growth vary, but all results show that NZVI can promote plant growth (Rico et al., 2015). AlthoughNZVI cannot completely prevent plant absorption of As, NZVI can reduce the availability of As, thus reducing toxicity levels (Gil-Diaz et al., 2016). Studies have shown that NZVI has the best effect in terms of removing absorbable Cu from plants at a 5% concentration, and the magnetic separation method can also effectively limit the accumulation of Cu in plants (Feng et al., 2016). Huang et al. found that the combination of NZVI and phytoremediation can reduce the acid soluble fraction of Pb, which is responsible for the reduced toxicity of heavy metals in sediments (Huang et al., 2018). Low concentrations of NZVI can improve the remediation efficiency of plants, and nanomaterials used in conjunction with plant remediation will also prove to be a promising technology (Gong et al., 2017). However, the impact of NZVI in reaction with pollutants on soil requires further study (Jiang et al., 2018).

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Nano TiO2 combined with plants
sections.text: In addition to some of the nanomaterials mentioned above, nano TiO2 is also widely used. It was reported that nano TiO2 could not only increase plant protein content but also increases the absorption of 133CS in plant roots and in surrounding soil (Singh and Lee, 2018). With an increase in the concentration of nano TiO2 in the soil, the accumulation of Cd in roots and buds of Gycin emax (L.) Merr. plants increases, and more accumulation occurs in the root than in the bud (Singh and Lee, 2016). In addition, the inhibition of cadmium toxicity in soil by nano TiO2 was achieved by improving the growth rate and photosynthetic rate (Singh and Lee, 2016). Other studies have found that nano TiO2 promoted an increase in the average root lengths of plants such as cucumber and onion plants (Andersen et al., 2016). Therefore, nano TiO2 can enhance the capacity for plants to absorb pollutants. Another study found that adding 0.01% nano TiO2 to soil can significantly increase the leaf area, root dry weight and stem length of leguminous crops (Abdel Latef et al., 2018).

sections.heading: 3.2.3. NHAP combined with plants
sections.text:
Canavalia gladiata can transfer large amounts of Cd to branches (Puga et al., 2015). The results indicate that the absorption of heavy metals by plants increases with an increase in metal concentrations
and with time after the addition of NHAP and NCB, showing that they are proportional to each other (Rico et al., 2015). Rapeseed and Helianthus annuus L. can be used to extract Cd from the soil (Sun et al., 2018). The addition of bentonite reduces the exchangeable fraction of Cd and converts most heavy metals into unusable heavy metals. The more bentonite is added to stalks and brown rice, the lower the Cd content (Sun et al., 2015) and the stronger the resulting remediation effect. Moreover, the addition of 5 g/kg NHAP to Pb-contaminated soil increased the removal rate of Pb (Jin et al., 2016) mainly because Lolium perenne L. has a stronger absorption effect on toxic substances (Ding et al., 2017). When pH b 5, the solubility of heavy metals in soil increases, andwhen pH N 5, heavymetals in soil are immobilized with little fluidity (Jin et al., 2016). It was found that NHAP can increase soil pH values and fix Pb, thus reducing Pb toxicity levels of Lolium perenne L. (Ding et al., 2017). The addition of NHAP can reduce Pb migration and bioavailability in soil, which has no significant influence on Lolium perenne L. growth and which only reduces Pb bioavailability and fluidity. The addition of bentonite reduced the exchangeable fraction of Cd and Pb and converted most heavy metals into unusable forms of heavy metals (Sun et al., 2015). NHAP had a strong fixation effect on Pb in contaminated soil (Ding et al., 2017). The concentration of heavy metals in roots of isolated Lolium perenne L. is high when combined with nanomaterials, and the removal rate of heavy metals and the biomass of Lolium perenne L. are in turn increased (Liang et al., 2017).

sections.heading: 3.2.4. Nanocomposite combined with plants
sections.text:
Heavy metals in soil cannot be decomposed and can only be transferred (Liang et al., 2017). Phytoremediation is supposed to transfer pollutants by extraction, adsorption and detoxification while this process takes a relatively long time to treat pollutants (Liang et al., 2017). Several researchers have conducted experimental studies that involve combining plants with composite nanomaterials. To observe the effect of nanomaterials on the plant absorption of Pb, NHAP and NCB have been added to soil. The combination of NZVI and NCB can not only reduce the toxicity of lead but can also increase the biomass of Lolium perenne L. (Liang et al., 2017) (Table 4). NHAP@BC has a strong effect on soil remediation and greatly reduces Pb availability in soil (Yang et al., 2016b). Liang et al. found that NHAP and NCB combined with Lolium perenne L. extracted Pb in soil over a short period. Similarly, the longer bentonite is added to strawand brown rice, the lower the Pb content (Sun et al., 2015). Zeolite and nano SiO2 can effectively reduce the migration capacity of Pb (Mousavi et al., 2018), thus reducing the availability andmigration of heavymetals in soil. After adding NHAP and BC, the absorption of heavy metals by plants was found to increase with an increase in metal concentration and time (Jin et al., 2016).
Effects of nanomaterials and plants for the remediation of soil contaminated with different metals and metalloids also vary. NZVI @BC can effectively reduce the upward translocation of Cd in plants, which is conducive to plant growth (Su et al., 2016). Ag can enhance the ecological functions of southern salt marshes and is conducive to plant
rehabilitation (Fernandes et al., 2017). When Cu exists as nanoparticles, the microflora structure of plant roots is changed, and in turn phytoremediation is affected (Fernandes et al., 2017).
In addition, Antonoglou and colleagues designed CuZn double metal nanomaterials using the microwave assisted method, which is of great help to agriculture, as these nanomaterials can be used for foliar spraying and limit the precipitation of heavy metals in soil (Antonoglou et al., 2018). Whether adding natural or synthetic chelators to soil can dissolve or absorb metals more easily for the removal of heavy metals remains to be investigated (Khalid et al., 2018). However, it has been proposed that the effect of nanomaterials on terrestrial plants is affected by various environmental factors (Reddy et al., 2016).
In addition to the nanomaterials described above researchers have used nano SiO2 to enhance the solubility of Secale rhizosphere Pb and Cd so that plants can better absorb heavy metals, thus improving the phytoremediation effect (Mousavi et al., 2018). All of the above results illustrate the influence of nanomaterials on plants or how the combination of nanomaterials and plants can be used to control soil pollution. However, the different effects of nanomaterials with different physicochemical properties on soil remediation by plants must be studied further (Zuverza-Mena et al., 2017).

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In this article, we have reviewed the recent progress on the study of nanomaterials and plants from three aspects including positive effects, toxicity and the remediation of metal and metalloid pollution in soil. With the continuous development of science and technology, nanomaterials are being more widely used for environmental remediation, through which synergism with plants can further improve the remediation efficiency of contaminated soil with metals and metalloids. Nanomaterials can change plant chlorophyll and carotene, increase plant protein levels, improve the rate of plant photosynthesis, promote growth, increase soil fertility, and reduce heavy metals availability and toxicity to plants. NZVI, nano TiO2, NHAP, and some nanocomposites are common nanomaterials for combination with plants to remediate the contaminated soil with metals and metalloids (e.g., Cd, Pb, As and Zn). However, nanomaterials are toxic to plants at high concentrations, mainly causing growth inhibition, different leaf toxicity reactions, etc.
In short, the ‘new’ technology by combining nanomaterials with plants for the remediation of soil pollution is promising, and may fast find its way in the large-scale practical applications. To achieve this, further research is needed on whether nanomaterials react with substances in soil after they enter, on whether they are toxic to soil and plants, on how to use nanomaterials under conditions of maximum utilization and minimum toxicity, and on whether there exist nontoxic nanomaterials at high concentrations or plants that can resist high concentrations of nanomaterials.

referenceMentions.context: In recent years, due to the continuous development of various industrial technologies (Xu et al., 2016b; Xu et al., 2017), some soil has been contaminated to varying degrees by different types of pollutants.

For example, the microbial remediation method is limited in that not all microbes are highly adaptable to the environment, which cannot guarantee the remediation of contaminated soil (Chen et al., 2015).
Thus, they are not the best tools for addressing issues of environmental pollution faced today (Chen et al., 2015).

Conversely, phytoremediation is a form of technology that uses green plants to transfer, transform, or absorb pollutants such as metals and metalloids (Jin et al., 2016) such that phytoremediation can limit their harm to the environment.

In recent years, several studies have proved that it is feasible to use nanomaterials to remediate different kinds of contaminants in soil such as nano TiO2, nano Fe3O4, nano Ag, NZVI (nano zero valent iron), nano CeO2, nano Zn, nano Co, nano Ni, nano SnO2, NHAP (nano hydroxyapatite), NCB (nano carbon black), and NHAP@BC (biochar supported nano hydroxyapatite), which can be used to remove metals such as Cr, Cu, Pb, Zn and Cd from soil (Zhang et al., 2018; Singh and Lee, 2016; Xing et al., 2016; Mousavi et al., 2018; Huang et al., 2018; Gong et al., 2017).
